content.webTitle: My gay divorce made me feel like I’d let the queer community down | Candice Gallimore

fields.headline: My gay divorce made me feel like I’d let the queer community down
fields.bodyText: November 15, 2017, 10am: I’m sitting in a corporate boardroom booked by the office queers so we could be together for the postal survey results. The room is heavy with anxiety and everyone is on edge unable to breath with much ease. I hold the hand next to me tightly as the room is fed the results – 61.6% yes – we all erupt with tears, hugs and cheers. We’d just spent the past few years battling the government to stop them from taking our right to marry to the polls and when we finally thought we’d won it was ripped away with this non-binding postal survey. Despite the defeat, as always, we got back up and spent the months leading up to 15 November having constant conversations, rallying, calling strangers and family members and watching on as the far right were given a platform to exercise their “freedom of speech”, which ultimately did damage to so many of us in the community. But while I attended the rallies, had the conversations and watched the hate unfold, I was harbouring what I felt was a dirty secret: I was a fraud. At that same time as the country was debating gay marriage, my “wife” of three years and partner of eight and I were going through our gay divorce. Despite this, it was empowering to be a part of the fight and it felt like I was at least doing something to help the cause. But the entire time I felt so guilty. How could I be fighting for the right to enter an institution that I was leaving? I felt like I’d let the community down and at the time I didn’t make my voice as loud as I would have liked to. My muted voice was for fear that those within and outside of the community would feel that I’d just added to the reasons for the no vote. Divorce in any community is often seen, or at least feels when you’re experiencing it, as a failure. However, I felt extra pressure that I suspect others in the queer community feel to show that a same-sex marriage, legal or otherwise, would last. With such a spotlight on the community especially during the plebiscite, there’s a sense that any wrong move is a chalk mark in the “cons” column for the rights of LGBTQI+ people and there feels like no bigger con mark than a failed marriage. When I first was married I found it difficult to talk about it to colleagues and strangers, for fear that they would tune out thinking “it’s not a real marriage” since it wasn’t yet legal in Australia. Then I felt I couldn’t talk about it as marriage equality became closer because the relationship had ended. While all my partnered friends were taking to social media sharing their stories of love and using these personal anecdotes to help sway voters, for the first time in eight years I felt as though I couldn’t contribute. It was a strange identity loss that I hadn’t expected to be amplified through the plebiscite campaign. No longer could I share the incredible photos of me looking handsome in a tailored suit and my bride looking beautiful in her white gown as proof that “love exists”. I didn’t feel comfortable sharing stories of the previous eight years, from falling in love with my roommate, to moving states together and enduring all the hardships that couples go through over the years only to come out victorious through it all. I could only sit in silence through the conversations hoping no one who knew would bring it up. On reflection though, why couldn’t I have these conversations or share these photos and memories? After all, heterosexuals have been divorcing since the 1500s. Why was my story of gay divorce not one to share during this time? My wife had rejected my suggestion to get “real married” during our honeymoon in Hawaii, so we ended up not having to go through a “real divorce”, but many people weren’t so lucky. Since the Marriage Act was redefined to be “the union of two people to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life”, while a lot of queer people and allies have been celebrating the right to marry, I’m finding myself thinking more about a right we didn’t talk much about: the right to divorce. Going through a breakup is hard enough but imagine knowing or maybe finding out through the process, that you’re stuck in a legal loophole. For all those couples rejoicing the fact that their overseas marriages to their same-sex partner were finally being recognised at home, there were those celebrating the recognition of divorce. Had we married in Hawaii we’d have a situation where we’d have split up and then had our marriage legally recognised by the change in laws in Australia and been forced through a formal divorce. The thought of being legally married after a split is distressing but it’s something that many couples would have gone through. As the people I went to high school with, teachers, old colleagues and many others who were silent all those years ago when I came out started changing their Facebook picture frames to a rainbow “Vote Yes” image and shared positive articles about gay marriage or horrific stories of queer people being treated poorly by businesses in the wedding industry, it felt particularly important to prove that they’d chosen the right side. I never expected to be someone to get married in the first place, so it came as a shock to me when on the cusp of 24 I found myself proposing to my long-term girlfriend. There was so much vocal celebration for our engagement and even more so at, and after, the wedding. Yet the decision I made to split up, just months before my 29th birthday, would ultimately be the best one I’d make for myself and my relationship, and no one celebrated. There were no congratulations on the divorce, no divorce parties where my friends could contribute to pay for half the shit I’d just lost. I had some quiet conversations with my best friend who was proud of my decision. And it took a year, but I finally got “good at being single”. I’ve never been happier and I make a point of saying this regularly, not because I need to convince myself but I feel like I need to convince those around me. I’ve come to new realisations about marriage equality. When I was first fighting for it, making creative signs for rallies that said things like “You can marry your cousin, but I can’t marry my girlfriend?” and “Legalise gay marriage … my arms are sore”, I was doing it for the very selfish and personal reason of my desire to get married. I wanted what my heterosexual peers had. I wanted to wear my wedding ring with pride, share the photos of the big day and have water cooler conversations about the things “my wife” did that made me proud, all without wondering if they were thinking “yeah it’s not real though, is it?” Since the divorce, the right to marry has taken on a whole new meaning for me. One that those fighting for my rights had no doubt been thinking about all along. It’s not about the right to get married. It’s not even really about the right to get divorced. It’s about the right. The human right to be treated the same as anyone else. The right to have the option. Candice Gallimore is a comedy performer and writer who lives in Sydney with a day job in marketing.
